planck_original_values.note: Planck used h, not ℏ = h/(2π); values updated to modern precision

temperature.note: Added later when Boltzmann constant k_B included

planck_quote.original_german: Diese Größen behalten ihre natürliche Bedeutung so lange, als die Gesetze der Gravitation, der Lichtfortpflanzung im Vakuum und die beiden Hauptsätze der Wärmetheorie in Gültigkeit bleiben
planck_quote.english_translation: These quantities retain their natural significance as long as the laws of gravitation, the propagation of light in a vacuum, and the two principles of thermodynamics remain valid
planck_quote.significance: Planck understood these were the most fundamental scales in physics

historical_timeline.event: Planck introduces natural units (ℓ_P, t_P, m_P)
historical_timeline.publication: Sitzungsberichte der Preußischen Akademie der Wissenschaften

historical_timeline.event: Planck derives blackbody radiation formula with h
Einstein: E = mc² and photon concept
Wheeler: Quantum foam at Planck scale

historical_timeline.significance: Planck units appear in fundamental formula

why_planck_chose_these_constants.c: Maximum speed in nature - connects space and time
why_planck_chose_these_constants.h: Quantum of action - minimum 'uncertainty' in nature
why_planck_chose_these_constants.combination: The ONLY dimensionless combination is Planck units (up to factors of 2π, etc.)

definition.@value: The historical development of Planck units from their introduction by Max Planck in 1899 to their modern significance in quantum gravity

related.relationship: Dimensional analysis gives Planck's original derivation

learning_objectives: Understand Planck's original motivation for natural units
Appreciate that Planck units predate quantum mechanics and GR
Recognize the universality argument: any civilization would find same units
Trace historical development from 1899 to modern quantum gravity
physics_insights: Planck introduced these units in 1899 - BEFORE quantum mechanics!
G, c, h uniquely determine ℓ_P, t_P, m_P through dimensional analysis
Planck's quote: valid 'as long as laws of gravitation and thermodynamics remain valid'
Modern significance not understood until Wheeler, Bekenstein, Hawking in 1950s-70s
